oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Preliminary Results on the Effect of Feeding Heat-treated Colostrum on Health and Growth in Pre-weaned Dairy Calves
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Donahue, M.
Godden, S.
Bey, R.
Wells, S.
Fetrow, J.
Stabel, J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: colostrum
heat-treatment
colostral bacteria
immunoglobulin
serum lgG
daily gain
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Previous research showed that heat-treatment of colostrum at 140°F (60°C) for 60 minutes results in a significant reduction in colostral bacteria counts without affecting colostral immunoglobulin concentrations. Moreover, calves fed heat-treated colostrum have improved serum lgG levels when compared to calves fed raw colostrum. It is unclear whether feeding heat-treated colostrum will improve growth or health in preweaned calves. The objective of this study was to describe the effect of feeding heat-treated colostrum on average daily gain (ADG), risk for morbidity, and mortality in pre-weaned calves.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2009; 187
